title: The US-China factor in Philippines’ Marcos-Duterte feud comes to the fore
description: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr’s assertiveness in the South China Sea dispute was an early sign of a rift between him and his former allies, the Dutertes. The programme Insight looks at the spillover effects of their feud.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Tensions with China have heightened as the Marcos government pivoted away from the Duterte administration’s policy of non-confrontation.

  • Since Vice President Sara Duterte quit the Cabinet, the feud between the two families has also escalated.

  • She has consistently out-polled Marcos in terms of approval ratings. But the gap has narrowed since the split, at least in one poll.

author: Lianne Chia

#attributes.alt: The US-China factor in Philippines’ Marcos-Duterte feud comes to the fore
#attributes.title: The US-China factor in Philippines’ Marcos-Duterte feud comes to the fore

title: ‘Last line of defence’: Meet the ‘$1 lawyers’ who provide justice for all
description: More young lawyers want to make a full-time career in giving free legal advice and representation, says charity Pro Bono SG, which has an office on the grounds of a temple. This, even as some cases are greeted with brickbats.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Pro Bono SG says more fresh law graduates are applying to join the charity full-time.

  • It has lawyers working in an office on the grounds of a Hougang temple, seeing clients who don’t know where else to go.

  • They sometimes take on cases that are greeted with brickbats, like the death of toddler Umaisyah. But the work has meaning, says one lawyer involved.

author: Lianne Chia

#attributes.alt: ‘Last line of defence’: Meet the ‘$1 lawyers’ who provide justice for all
#attributes.title: ‘Last line of defence’: Meet the ‘$1 lawyers’ who provide justice for all

title: Is Seoul ‘sucking all the good’ from South Korea? Here’s why rural areas are emptying out
description: Metropolises are a target destination in many countries; South Korea is no exception. But what will become of its rural regions when they are bleeding young talent at breakneck speed? The programme Insight explores the issue and possible solutions.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Between 2015 and 2021, youths accounted for 78.5 per cent of the internal migration to the greater Seoul area.

  • But Seoul’s high-pressure, high-cost environment stymies marriage and family planning.

  • One trillion won (S$979 million) per year has been allocated for revitalising depopulated areas. But to boost birth rates, more solutions are needed.

author: Faith Leong

#attributes.alt: Is Seoul ‘sucking all the good’ from South Korea? Here’s why rural areas are emptying out
#attributes.title: Is Seoul ‘sucking all the good’ from South Korea? Here’s why rural areas are emptying out

title: Trial programme gets children to befriend seniors — 5 reasons to watch this CNA series
description: A 10-week inter-generation programme explores how forming friendships across ages can foster a happier, more compassionate society. CNA series It Takes A Village documents this journey undertaken by six pairs of children and seniors.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• A 10-week inter-generation programme between seniors and pre-schoolers was recently trialled in Singapore.

  • CNA’s four-part series, It Takes A Village, documented this journey undertaken by six pairs of children and seniors.

  • Highlights include the children hopping into the motorised bed of one of the nursing home residents for a quick “ride”.

author: Liew Zhi Xin

#attributes.alt: Trial programme gets children to befriend seniors — 5 reasons to watch this CNA series
#attributes.title: Trial programme gets children to befriend seniors — 5 reasons to watch this CNA series

title: Our waters aren’t ‘boring’: Meet the disabled diver who photographs Singapore’s sea critters
description: With only one functioning arm, Kelvin Pung is on a quest to document and promote the island’s aquatic gems such as the Pikachu nudibranch. The programme On The Red Dot finds out how his efforts are quietly paying off.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Although he has lost the use of one arm, swimming is easy for Kelvin Pung; suiting up for each dive is the challenge.
  • Still, he is an avid underwater photographer who hopes to promote local marine wildlife through his photos.
  • Together with fellow divers, he is quietly making an impact, with new biodiversity records being discovered in Singapore.

author: Liew Zhi Xin

#attributes.alt: Our waters aren’t ‘boring’: Meet the disabled diver who photographs Singapore’s sea critters
#attributes.title: Our waters aren’t ‘boring’: Meet the disabled diver who photographs Singapore’s sea critters

title: Why Japan’s youth are lonelier than their elders — even embracing solitude, at great social cost
description: Japanese society teeters between strict self-restraint and sinking into chronic loneliness, with its youth on the brink. The programme Insight delves into the trend towards loneliness and what the country can do to combat it.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• While Japan is known for its social insularity, those in their 20s and 30s report the highest levels of loneliness.

  • “Solo katsu” is now a trend as more young Japanese try activities on their own. But feelings of loneliness can escalate.

  • Japan recently passed a law requiring local governments to establish support groups for those in need owing to loneliness and isolation.

author: Faith Leong

#attributes.alt: Why Japan’s youth are lonelier than their elders — even embracing solitude, at great social cost
#attributes.title: Why Japan’s youth are lonelier than their elders — even embracing solitude, at great social cost

title: Gen Z Filipinos, the loneliest youths in Southeast Asia, are struggling. This is how and why
description: The pandemic and heavy use of social media are just two of the contributing factors to the social isolation faced by the country’s youth. The programme Insight delves deeper and finds out what is being done to help them.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• According to a Meta-Gallup report, the Philippines is the world’s second-loneliest country.

  • Experts say Gen Z is one of the loneliest age groups, and last year, the WHO declared loneliness a global health threat.

  • Among young Filipinos, levels of loneliness have been elevated by the pandemic, overuse of social media and parents working overseas.

author: Lianne Chia

#attributes.alt: Gen Z Filipinos, the loneliest youths in Southeast Asia, are struggling. This is how and why
#attributes.title: Gen Z Filipinos, the loneliest youths in Southeast Asia, are struggling. This is how and why

title: Panda Power: The Rise of Furry Diplomats - US-China rivalry: Why America is losing pandas - but it won’t be forever
landing_page_headline: US-China rivalry: Why America is losing pandas - but it won’t be forever
description:
"Pandas have helped to mend US-China relations twice in the past. Is it about to happen again?

The United State’s last pandas are set to leave Zoo Atlanta by the end of 2024, when their loan from China expires. While some see the withdrawing of these diplomatic creatures as China’s way of retaliating amidst heightened tensions with the US, there might be hope. In November 2023, Chinese President Xi Jinping promised at a business dinner that San Diego Zoo would get pandas again."

title: Dead Alone In Singapore - Don't let me die solo: how can we prevent lonely deaths?
landing_page_headline: Don't let me die solo: how can we prevent lonely deaths?
description:
"There’s a growing group of retirees in Singapore who are living out their golden years in poor health and little social support. Their greatest fear? To die without anyone noticing.

Those who died and went undiscovered for days are getting younger - the median age was 66 based on reported incidents in 2023. Can community efforts ensure these seniors have the choice of dying with dignity? "

Here’s how Singaporean artist Andrea Lee turned her childhood hobby of collecting dolls into a side-hustle - with her creations that cost up to US$6,000, selling out within minutes.

title: Walk The Line -  Why we left China with our 13-year-old, and risked our lives to get to the US illegally
landing_page_headline: Why we left China with our 13-year-old, and risked our lives to get to the US illegally
description: Dad, Mum, and 13-year-old Lucy departed Chengdu, China with hopes of illegally entering the United States. They are part of a growing trend called ‘zou xian’ or ‘Walk The Line’ in Chinese internet slang, referring to those who take long and arduous detours to America. Their journey across the continent started in Ecuador, spanning 7 countries and 6,000km.

landing_page_headline: How Marcos family & supporters are rewriting history online: Digital activists fight misinformation
description: On average, more than 376 edits are made on Ferdinand Marcos Sr's Wikipedia page every year, with certain editors returning to ‘sanitise’ the page. Digital activists believe that since the 2000s, the Marcos family and its supporters have been distorting and editing content on social media and the Internet about Philippine history, especially the martial law years, to gain favour with the public.

title: ‘World’s worst drivers’: Are Singaporeans as bad as they proclaim each other to be?
description: Singaporean drivers have a notorious reputation, but are bad driving skills or a poor driving culture the main culprit? The programme Talking Point sends its hosts to find out and asks viewers which group of drivers are the worst.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• At 13.64 deaths per 100,000 vehicles, Singapore’s fatality rate is more than four times the rate in Japan.

  • Bumper-to-bumper traffic aside, driving skills and attitudes contribute to Singaporean drivers’ bad rap, for several reasons.

  • A poll of about 2,000 respondents concludes that private hire and taxi drivers are the country’s worst motorists.

author: Faith Leong

#attributes.alt: ‘World’s worst drivers’: Are Singaporeans as bad as they proclaim each other to be?

title: I spent 14 years as a stay-at-home dad for my son. Here’s why it’s time to reclaim my life
landing_page_headline: I spent 14 years as a stay-at-home dad for my son. Here’s why it’s time to reclaim my life
description: “Why is an able-bodied man being a stay-home dad?” For 14 years, Lee Kwong Luen, a father of two, dedicated his time and energy to caring full-time for his son Jue Ming, who has autism and bleeding disorder haemophilia B. He candidly shares the criticism he faces, his struggle with social isolation and depression, and how he’s slowly reclaiming his identity after putting his career and life on hold.

title: What happens to retired MRT trains? How Singapore gives them new life
landing_page_headline: What happens to retired MRT trains? How Singapore gives them new life
description: In 2023, Singapore’s Land Transport Authority (LTA) decommissioned about 12 of the North-South and East-West Lines’ first- to third-generation trains to make way for newer train models. About 2,600 tonnes of train parts were disposed of — but the LTA has found ways to reuse these parts to cut waste and keep the trains’ history alive.

title: Walk The Line - Following Chinese Migrants’ Journey To US Border
landing_page_headline: Following Chinese migrants’ journey to US border
description:
From the same producer of the hit series ‘One Way’, Wei Du and her team present a new documentary, ‘Walk The Line’.

Chinese citizens are the fastest-growing group of illegal migrants entering the United States (US). For weeks, CNA followed some of them across South America, as they navigated a complex web of human smugglers, drug cartels, and border officials to reach the US southern border. The migrants’ perilous journey includes crossing the Darien Gap, a dense, paramilitary-controlled jungle that is one of the world’s most dangerous migration routes.

video.label: Following Chinese Migrants’ Journey To US Border
video.caption:
From the same producer of the hit series ‘One Way’, Wei Du and her team present a new documentary, ‘Walk The Line’. 

Chinese citizens are the fastest-growing group of illegal migrants entering the United States (US). For weeks, CNA followed some of them across South America, as they navigated a complex web of human smugglers, drug cartels, and border officials to reach the US southern border. The migrants’ perilous journey includes crossing the Darien Gap, a dense, paramilitary-controlled jungle that is one of the world’s most dangerous migration routes.

author: Wei Du

title: Talking Point 2024/2025 - Talking Point is on a rat hunt and we need your help!
landing_page_headline: Talking Point is on a rat hunt and we need your help!
description:
"Singapore is facing a growing rat problem. The National Environment Agency (NEA) said it detected more than 5,000 burrows in 2023 - an increase of 1,000 from the previous year - and there could be many more undetected.

Steven Chia and the #TalkingPoint team are mapping out rat activity across Singapore and your sightings will help us track where rodent populations are in real-time, pinpoint some of the hotspots, and what’s being done about these pests. Check out the rat map here: http://cna.asia/ratmap

Share your sightings with us via email at TalkingPoint [at] mediacorp.com.sg, WhatsApp at 9124 3305, or DM @cnainsider on Instagram."

title: Before going pro Down Under, Danelle Tan offers inside look at her life in German football
description: This 19-year-old Singaporean made history playing for Borussia Dortmund. The programme On The Red Dot joined her at the club before she traded lower-league European football for a professional contract in Australia’s top women’s division.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Danelle Tan may have made history in Borussia Dortmund, but she was not paid, let alone making a living playing football.
  • That is about to change, following her decision to play professionally in Australia’s top women’s division.
  • Her time in Dortmund, including her skills training in its famous Footbonaut pioneered by Jurgen Klopp, has helped.

author: Derrick A Paulo

title: She makes hyper-realistic baby dolls for a living. They go for as much as US$6,000
description: Cradling a lifelike baby doll may seem eerie to some, but for Andrea Lee, who creates about 26 of them a year, it is comforting and beautiful. CNA Insider explores the reborn-doll market and what fuels its appeal.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Andrea Lee paints doll sculptures to resemble human babies, selling her creations online and garnering a following among doll collectors.

  • She specialises in silicone dolls, which can fetch up to US$10,000. Her most expensive doll sold for more than US$5,900.

  • Before the dolls are “reborn”, they undergo three stages: creation, detailing and dress-up.

author: Faith Leong

#attributes.alt: She makes hyper-realistic baby dolls for a living. They go for as much as US$6,000
#attributes.title: She makes hyper-realistic baby dolls for a living. They go for as much as US$6,000

title: This 25-year-old has life-limiting muscular dystrophy. It’s not stopping him from cosplaying
description: It is not about counting down the days for Toh Wee Yang but about making each day count. CNA Insider joined him at a cosplay event he mooted and met the many people who rallied to his support.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Toh Wee Yang has Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is characterised by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness.

  • Though bedridden, he had an idea for a cosplay event where he’d dress as an anime character who has a similar condition.

  • HCA Hospice rallied the cosplay community to fulfil his wish and spread his message of hope and inspiration.

author: Faith Leong

#attributes.alt: This 25-year-old has life-limiting muscular dystrophy. It’s not stopping him from cosplaying
#attributes.title: This 25-year-old has life-limiting muscular dystrophy. It’s not stopping him from cosplaying

title: How to beat the heat in Singapore, without air-conditioning
description: About 20 per cent of Singapore’s resident households do not have an air-conditioner. What is their life like struggling with heat? The programme Talking Point shares one family’s experience and gets cooling advice from a team of experts.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Experts have embarked on a project to study how households cope with heat and to develop new, cheaper cooling strategies.
  • The researchers found solutions for one family in a rental flat, among the 20 per cent of resident households without air-con.
  • The HDB is also looking to cool down its towns by, for example, piloting a heat-reflective paint.

author: Derrick A Paulo

#attributes.alt: How to beat the heat in Singapore, without air-conditioning
#attributes.title: How to beat the heat in Singapore, without air-conditioning

title: Are you lonely in Singapore? A call for honest reflections
description: #WHOISCHECKINGIN is a new campaign by Talking Point that aims to find out how lonely young adults in Singapore are.
author: Faith Leong

#attributes.alt: Are you lonely in Singapore? A call for honest reflections
#attributes.title: Are you lonely in Singapore? A call for honest reflections

title: 3 reasons to watch CNA’s 3-part series on dying alone in Singapore
description: Dying alone is an increasingly grim reality in Singapore. CNA’s latest trilogy delves into the identities of elderly individuals in danger of suffering this fate, the factors contributing to their solitude and ongoing efforts to support them.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Last year, the media reported at least 37 lonely deaths in Singapore. Experts believe more cases go unreported.

  • A CNA series now finds out the nuanced truths of dying alone from those at risk and from witnesses to these events.

  • The elderly folk include a 65-year-old who does not close the door of his flat so he can be found quickly if he dies.

author: Faith Leong

#attributes.alt: 3 reasons to watch CNA’s 3-part series on dying alone in Singapore
#attributes.title: 3 reasons to watch CNA’s 3-part series on dying alone in Singapore

title: Invisible, incurable, constantly in pain: This is what living with fibromyalgia is like
description: Imagine doctors insisting that you are fine, when your body is engulfed in pain. Four fibromyalgia patients tell CNA Insider about their struggles with this invisible illness and how they draw strength from their suffering.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Not only is fibromyalgia invisible, it also does not cause any observable bodily damage. There are no medical tests for it.

  • Patients may struggle with isolation or anxiety over the material and emotional strains placed on loved ones.

  • While there is no one-size-fits-all approach to managing symptoms, finding a supportive community is recommended.

author: Faith Leong

#attributes.alt: Invisible, incurable, constantly in pain: This is what living with fibromyalgia is like
#attributes.title: Invisible, incurable, constantly in pain: This is what living with fibromyalgia is like

title: Made in China, for China: Is patriotism the answer to its weakening economy?
description: With China’s growth target of 5 per cent this year deemed ambitious, the programme Insight looks at the factors behind its economic challenges and whether relying on innovation and domestic spending can steer its economy towards recovery.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Among Chinese youth, there is a growing trend towards home-grown products instead of foreign ones.

• With its rise stymied by geopolitical tensions and its property market turmoil, China wants more of its citizens to buy local.

• But domestic consumption is a weak link in the Chinese economy, and Beijing is also pinning its hopes on high-tech exports.

author: Faith Leong

#attributes.alt: Made in China, for China: Is patriotism the answer to its weakening economy?
#attributes.title: Made in China, for China: Is patriotism the answer to its weakening economy?

title: Technology to mitigate dangers of air turbulence? There’s a possible solution
description: Following the severe turbulence that hit SQ321, the programme Talking Point finds out more about a technology commonly used in self-driving cars that could help passengers to stay safe when they fly.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Research suggests that Lidar, commonly used in self-driving cars, can detect clear-air turbulence up to 32 km ahead of an aircraft.

• But to be deployed effectively at high altitudes, it requires a lot of processing power and a big system unit.

• In the most optimistic case, the technology could level up in three years’ time, says an avionics expert.

author: Derrick A Paulo

#attributes.alt: Technology to mitigate dangers of air turbulence? There’s a possible solution
#attributes.title: Technology to mitigate dangers of air turbulence? There’s a possible solution

title: Why the West fears massive job losses because of China’s clean tech prowess
description: European and American leaders have accused Beijing of violating market principles in the electric vehicle, solar panel and battery sectors. The programme When Titans Clash finds out if another China trade shock is on the cards.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Some Western leaders have accused Beijing of violating market principles in electric vehicles, solar panels and batteries.

• These sectors now play an important role in powering China’s economy, and Beijing has pushed back against the allegation.

• Amid the geopolitical tussle, some economists warn of an impending China shock in advanced manufacturing.

author: Pearl Forss

#attributes.alt: Why the West fears massive job losses because of China’s clean tech prowess
#attributes.title: Why the West fears massive job losses because of China’s clean tech prowess

title: Thailand is one of the world’s fastest-ageing developing nations. This is how it happened
description: The kingdom’s population may halve before the turn of the century. The programme Insight delves into the reasons, and the possible solutions to a fertility decline that poses unique challenges.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Thailand’s fertility rate — at 1.08 last year — is the second lowest in Southeast Asia after Singapore’s.
  • According to a public survey last September, 44 per cent of respondents expressed a lack of desire to have children.
  • Deputy PM Somsak Thepsutin has warned that persisting on this trajectory could halve the Thai population within 60 years.

author: Faith Leong

#attributes.alt: Thailand is one of the world’s fastest-ageing developing nations. This is how it happened
#attributes.title: Thailand is one of the world’s fastest-ageing developing nations. This is how it happened

title: Distracted walking: A habit that can affect your body, brain
description: With the streets swarming with ‘petextrians’, concern over road safety looms ever larger. The programme Talking Point explores what happens when phone users walk distractedly and how Singapore can change this habit.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• As early as 2015, a survey done by NTU students found that 93 per cent of 419 youths admitted to multi-tasking while walking.

  • There is a big drop-off in brain function as the brain can become overburdened with distractions, warns a neurosurgeon.

  • Over time, distracted walkers may also experience “text neck” syndrome, which affects neck posture.

author: Faith Leong

#attributes.alt: Distracted walking: A habit that can affect your body, brain
#attributes.title: Distracted walking: A habit that can affect your body, brain

title: Rats are a growing problem in Singapore. Here are the hotspots and what’s being done
description: Toa Payoh, Tampines and Hougang are the areas with the most rat sightings, according to reports CNA Insider and the programme Talking Point received from readers and viewers across the island.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Based on NEA surveillance figures, more rat burrows are being detected than before.

  • Toa Payoh, Tampines and Hougang saw the most rat sightings, according to Talking Point and CNA Insider’s viewers and readers.

  • Their reports were collated to create a rat map and led SportSG, for example, to ramp up pest control efforts at ActiveSG facilities.

author: Derrick A Paulo

#attributes.alt: Rats are a growing problem in Singapore. Here are the hotspots and what’s being done
#attributes.title: Rats are a growing problem in Singapore. Here are the hotspots and what’s being done

title: Producers of Walk The Line reveal what it took to film Chinese migrants going to US illegally
description: Late last year, a CNA crew travelled to North and South America to document the journeys of Chinese citizens crossing borders as illegal immigrants. The team behind Walk The Line now shares how the series was made.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Recently, a CNA crew flew to the Americas to film the journeys of Chinese citizens crossing borders illegally.

  • Given the risks involved, CNA hired a security firm, and a former British Army medic accompanied the crew on the whole trip.

  • It was “emotionally difficult” when they could not offer to help the migrants, shared CNA correspondent Wei Du.

author: Derrick A Paulo

#attributes.alt: Producers of Walk The Line reveal what it took to film Chinese migrants going to US illegally
#attributes.title: Producers of Walk The Line reveal what it took to film Chinese migrants going to US illegally

title: Decline of the ringgit: Amid strain on people, businesses, is there hope for a rebound?
description: After the currency hit a 26-year low, is the only way up? The programme Insight finds optimism and doubt in equal measure as it looks at factors behind the ringgit’s fall and the ripple effects.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• The impact of the depreciating ringgit extends across income brackets as people and businesses grapple with imported inflation.

  • Experts cite the increased interest rates in the US as a “major factor” driving the currency’s slide.

  • The government expects the ringgit to recover later this year, but its economy still needs a more competitive edge.

author: Faith Leong

#attributes.alt: Decline of the ringgit: Amid strain on people, businesses, is there hope for a rebound?
#attributes.title: Decline of the ringgit: Amid strain on people, businesses, is there hope for a rebound?

title: Must-watch: Chinese migrants are entering US illegally. We follow their perilous odyssey
description: The Chinese are the fastest-growing migrant group at the US’ southern border. The CNA documentary Walk The Line tells their stories as they attempt one of the world’s most dangerous migration routes, starting in South America.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Last year, over 37,400 Chinese migrants entered the US illegally from Mexico, more than 50 times the number in 2021.

• They mostly start off in South America, enduring robberies, police extortion and treks through drug-cartel territory.

• The coming CNA series, Walk The Line, followed some of them to find out how and why they are risking their lives.

author: Derrick A Paulo

#attributes.alt: Must-watch: Chinese migrants are entering US illegally. We follow their perilous odyssey
#attributes.title: Must-watch: Chinese migrants are entering US illegally. We follow their perilous odyssey

title: Your reusable water bottle may be dirtier than you think. Here’s what you can do
description: Lots of Singaporeans carry water bottles, but how many are aware of the bacteria and mould we gulp down with every use? The programme Talking Point examines common hygiene habits and how to avoid potential health risks.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• According to a Talking Point poll, 11 per cent of 1,100-plus respondents washed their water bottles once a month.

  • Tests showed that a bottle used simply to store water in the fridge had the highest mould count out of 10 bottles tested.

  • Rinsing a bottle without soap or using it only for drinking water is not a safeguard against bacterial growth.

author: Faith Leong

#attributes.alt: Your reusable water bottle may be dirtier than you think. Here’s what you can do
#attributes.title: Your reusable water bottle may be dirtier than you think. Here’s what you can do

title: Inside Malaysia’s express buses: From Singapore to KL, with caution
description: Between 2022 and this March, there were at least 32 reports of express bus accidents in Malaysia. The programme Talking Point digs into the safety issues and finds out what travellers should do if they meet with an accident.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Between 2022 and this March, there were at least 32 reports of express bus accidents. Nine cases involved passengers from Singapore

  • The bulk of the accidents happened late at night or in the early hours.

  • Drivers cite speeding and fatigue as reasons for this trend. A transport consultant says bus operators’ financial viability is a factor too.

author: Derrick A Paulo

#attributes.alt: Inside Malaysia’s express buses: From Singapore to KL, with caution
#attributes.title: Inside Malaysia’s express buses: From Singapore to KL, with caution

title: The Gulf beckons to more Asians. This is how they’re answering the call
description: A former commando from Singapore, a national footballer from Indonesia, an AI expert from China — they are some of the Asian migrants eyeing new heights in the Middle East. The documentary Gulf Falcons tells their stories.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• As the Gulf states work hard to diversify their economies, they have gone all out to attract foreign talent.

• One of the front-runners in the race to a post-oil future is the UAE, but neighbours like Saudi Arabia are catching up.

• The two countries have expats from Singapore, Indonesia and China, among others, in sectors like AI, events and sport.

author: Derrick A Paulo

title: Meet the ICU nurse who examines and diagnoses patients like a boss
description: When Faith Hwang told her parents she wanted to be a nurse, they thought it was a job with no career progression. As an advanced practice nurse at Tan Tock Seng Hospital, she is proving otherwise — to their delight now.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Faith Hwang is the first advanced practice nurse (APN) in a medical intensive care unit in Tan Tock Seng Hospital.

• She has the training to diagnose conditions, order tests and perform complex procedures like a bedside heart ultrasound.

• Her career choice surprised her parents at first, but their perceptions changed especially when she pursued her master’s.

author: Lin Yanqin

#attributes.alt: Meet the ICU nurse who examines and diagnoses patients like a boss
#attributes.title: Meet the ICU nurse who examines and diagnoses patients like a boss

title: Dupes have become more popular with young consumers. Are they really a good bargain?
description: Dupes, short for duplicates, are not quite copies of branded items. But that is not stopping what seems to be a growing consumption trend. The programme Talking Point delves into dupe culture and puts some products to the test.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Whereas there may be a stigma to buying knockoffs among older consumers, Gen Zers love it when they score a dupe.

• The most popular dupe category in Singapore and China is clothing, the programme Talking Point found.

• But dupes occupy a grey area, and there’s a legal minefield. Uniqlo, for example, is suing Shein for copying its popular shoulder bag.

author: Derrick A Paulo

#attributes.alt: Dupes have become more popular with young consumers. Are they really a good bargain?
#attributes.title: Dupes have become more popular with young consumers. Are they really a good bargain?

title: Not quite the Bali it used to be? This is what overtourism is doing to the island
description: As travellers flock to the island possibly in record numbers this year, the programme Insight explores what lies behind the locals’ love-hate relationship with tourism and what can be done to stem the feelings of discontent.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Bali launched a new tourism police unit in February to deal with problematic foreign and domestic tourists.
  • Its government has also levied a tourist tax of IDR150,000 since Feb 14 to preserve its culture and environment.
  • Mass tourism is straining Bali’s resources and tarnishing its image owing to rampant development, overcrowding and gridlock.

author: Derrick A Paulo

#attributes.alt: Not quite the Bali it used to be? This is what overtourism is doing to the island

title: When Titans Clash - Will the world give up European cars for Made-In-China electric vehicles?
landing_page_headline: Will the world give up European cars for Made-In-China electric vehicles?
description:
China emerged as one of the world’s top car exporters in 2023, powered by its massive push for electric vehicles. Buoyed by years of heavy government investments, subsidies, and manufacturing rebates, Chinese automakers have flooded overseas markets as global EV demand continues to rise. In Q4 2023, China’s BYD even outsold Tesla in sales volume for the first time.

Amid the advent of Chinese brands like NIO and Xpeng, the European Union launched an anti-subsidy investigation into China’s EV trade practices in late 2023. The move prompted swift retaliation from China, sparking concerns about a trade war.

video.label: Will the world give up European cars for Made-In-China electric vehicles?
video.caption:
China emerged as one of the world’s top car exporters in 2023, powered by its massive push for electric vehicles. Buoyed by years of heavy government investments, subsidies, and manufacturing rebates, Chinese automakers have flooded overseas markets as global EV demand continues to rise. In Q4 2023, China’s BYD even outsold Tesla in sales volume for the first time. 

Amid the advent of Chinese brands like NIO and Xpeng, the European Union launched an anti-subsidy investigation into China’s EV trade practices in late 2023. The move prompted swift retaliation from China, sparking  concerns about a trade war.

Indonesian Imam Januar has built and grown various YouTube channels such as RB Official which currently has over 10 million subscribers.

Now, he’s teaching content creation and monetisation classes to aspiring YouTubers and is building a ‘creator house’ in the village of Tapen Bondowoso in East Java.

title: This Way Up - Chinese husband and wife make truck deliveries along one of world’s highest trade routes
landing_page_headline: Chinese husband and wife make truck deliveries along one of world’s highest trade routes
description:
For Zhang Yao Quan, a long-haul truck driver who livestreams his journeys, bringing his wife along on deliveries is the safest way to survive Asia’s most dangerous roads like the Karakoram Highway.

They cook, eat, and sleep in the truck almost 24/7 in order to make deliveries on time. And being together within confined spaces also causes tensions to rise quickly.

title: Love Delayed - K-drama vs reality: Why South Koreans love fantasy romance but remain single and childless
landing_page_headline: K-drama vs reality: Why South Koreans love fantasy romance but remain single and childless
description:
Are expectations of the young falling short of the perfect romance seen in Korean dramas?

Seven out of ten South Koreans think cohabiting is a better idea than marriage, according to the 2022 Korea Social Survey. The country already has the lowest birthrate in the world - why does marriage seem like a bad idea in South Korea?

Living together before marriage is still a taboo, but check out how some South Koreans are willing to challenge social norms.

title: Remembering Me - The moment mum & dad ‘meet’ their dead son again: Coping with grief through VR tech
landing_page_headline: The moment mum & dad ‘meet’ their dead son again: Coping with grief through VR tech
description:
After losing their 12-year-old son, Raphael, to cancer in 2020, William and Winnie Lee were given a rare opportunity to preserve his memory in an unusual way. CNA producers helped them create a virtual reality (VR) avatar in his likeness so they could ‘interact’ with him in the metaverse.

Phuket is seeing a post-pandemic property boom, as wealthy Russians seek new investment and home opportunities amid the Ukraine war. Aided by relaxed visa rules and legal loopholes, Russians became the island’s second largest group of foreign condominium buyers after Chinese clients in 2023.

title: This Way Up - I’m a rare female truck driver in India and this is how I survive
landing_page_headline: I’m a rare female truck driver in India and this is how I survive
description:
Yogita Raghuvanshi has been a long-haul trucker in India for over 20 years. She drives through rain in the foggy mountains of Cherrapunji, one of the world's wettest regions, to pick up goods.
She talks about the dangers of her job, tricks to survive in harsh environments as a woman, and being away from her children for long periods.

title: This is why parents go to great lengths to conquer PSLE. But what do their children say?
description: Have Singapore’s views on academic results shifted, even a bit, since a change of the PSLE scoring system in 2021? The programme Regardless of Grades looks at how parents are approaching the exam and what it is doing to children.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• In a survey of 1,000 parents, 99 per cent say good PSLE scores are important. It is the first such survey since the change of scoring system in 2021.
  • Some parents are attending tuition workshops to be better prepared for the national exam.
  • Responses from children indicate that the biggest stressor in their PSLE journey is their parents.

author: Derrick A Paulo

#attributes.alt: This is why parents go to great lengths to conquer PSLE. But what do their children say?
#attributes.title: This is why parents go to great lengths to conquer PSLE. But what do their children say?

title: ‘We want to honour our students’ responses’: Chief marker lifts veil on PSLE marking process
description: How are the papers marked? How fair or strict are the markers? What should pupils do for a good result? PSLE science chief marker Jay Mahardale tackles these issues and more.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Markers are more accepting of alternative responses than before, in both science and mathematics papers.
  • They look at sample scripts to get a sense of pupils’ answers to the questions before updating the marking scheme.
  • Where pupils make a common mistake is that they cram in information instead of answering to the question.

author: Derrick A Paulo

#attributes.alt: ‘We want to honour our students’ responses’: Chief marker lifts veil on PSLE marking process
#attributes.title: ‘We want to honour our students’ responses’: Chief marker lifts veil on PSLE marking process

title: Insight 2023/2024 - US or China: Who will win the AI and Green Tech race?
landing_page_headline: US or China: Who Will Win The AI and Green Tech Race?
description:
China aims to be global leader in artificial intelligence (AI) and renewable energy. It has doubled down on investments and infrastructure support for these sectors - to rival the US.

But China’s growing dominance has also got some countries worried. The US-China trade war intensified last August, when President Joe Biden banned the export of advanced chips to China. The EU also has plans to ban Chinese solar panels.

China also faces barriers in AI advancement. From data security concerns to the US’ export controls on semiconductor technologies - can China emerge as the new global superpower?

video.label: US or China: Who will win the AI and Green Tech race?

China aims to be global leader in artificial intelligence (AI) and renewable energy. It has doubled down on investments and infrastructure support for these sectors - to rival the US.

title: Remembering World War ll pilot & Singapore’s Last Flying Tiger: Captain Ho Weng Toh
description: During World War II, an American-Chinese coalition called the “Flying Tigers” fought against the Japanese in Asia. Among its volunteer pilots was Captain Ho Weng Toh, who completed 18 missions over China on the B-25 Mitchell, bombing strategic points to push back Japanese soldiers. After the war, he became a pioneer Singapore Airlines pilot. Ho passed away at 103 on January 6, 2024.

title: Living with chronic pain that even doctors don’t believe - This is fibromyalgia
landing_page_headline: Living with chronic pain that even doctors don’t believe - This is fibromyalgia
description:
People with fibromyalgia feel widespread pain - but their medical tests come back normal. Not only does this baffle doctors, patients also question if their constant muscle aches, joint pain, and tiredness were simply imagined.

Fibromyalgia has no known cause or cure, and its symptoms - such as chronic fatigue, depression and brain fog - can be mistaken for other conditions like arthritic or autoimmune diseases. Four people share what it’s like to live with it, and the challenges of getting a diagnosis.

video.label: Living with chronic pain that even doctors don’t believe - This is fibromyalgia

title: The Exiles - How we investigated secret deportations of Asians from UK & Australia: The making of The Exiles
landing_page_headline: How we investigated secret deportations of Asians from UK & Australia: The making of The Exiles
description: CNA’s award-winning two-part documentary The Exiles highlighted the racially-motivated deportations of Asian men from post-World War Two Australia and the United Kingdom. Series producer and director Tom St John Gray talks about what went into the team's year-long investigations, and how he followed the trail of maritime records - including previously classified government records. They also had to track down family members and descendants of the missing across the world.

title: How tree doctors keep Singapore’s 2 million urban trees healthy
description:
Singapore’s NParks has over 250 ‘tree doctors’ who keep 2 million urban trees healthy. Arborists manage and inspect roadside and park trees regularly for signs of disease or issues that might make them prone to falling in strong winds.

With the nation’s goal of planting one million more trees by 2030, NParks has deployed what might be the world’s first Remote Tree Management System of its kind, which uses a roving scanner to collect data, making arborists’ work less laborious. It’s currently deployed at the Singapore Botanic Gardens and Jurong Lake Gardens.

title: Sing To Remember - I became dad's caregiver at 29: My top tips on dealing with dementia
landing_page_headline: I became Dad's caregiver at 29: My top tips on dealing with dementia
description:
At 29, Daniel Lim became his family’s sole breadwinner when his dad, Peter, was diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease while his mum was receiving treatment for breast cancer. Back in 2009, caregiving resources were scarce, and Daniel had to deal with financial woes, loneliness and caregiver’s burnout.

14 years on, Daniel has created a support system that taps on his neighbours, friends and even the neighbourhood barber to help with caregiving responsibilities. He also co-founded Enable Asia, a support group for fellow caregivers.

In this video, Daniel shares the lessons he learnt in 15 years of caregiving and tips on how to make it work.

title: Debt Bomb - Why 70 countries in debt could spark the biggest global economic crisis since 1929
landing_page_headline: Why 70 countries in debt could spark the biggest global economic crisis since 1929
description: Some 70 countries are in or at risk of debt distress - a record number that has the World Bank sounding the alarm. Debt defaults by these emerging and developing countries could lead the world into a global financial crisis perhaps even on par with the Great Depression of 1929. The pattern is clear from three previous debt waves: the Latin American debt crisis of the 1980s, Asian financial crisis of the 1990s, and the global financial crisis triggered by the 2007 US subprime crisis.

title: Insight 2023/2024 - Why is Joshimath, India’s Himalayan holy town, sinking?
landing_page_headline: Why is Joshimath, India’s Himalayan holy town, sinking?
description:
In early 2023, buildings collapsed overnight in the holy Indian pilgrimage town of Joshimath, displacing thousands of locals from their homes.

Experts were not surprised. The sacred Himalayan town lies along a steep mountain slope, perched atop an unstable, shifting foundation including landslide debris. Rampant construction and climate change in recent years have strained this fragile base.

Joshimath’s precarious story serves as a dire warning to other mountain towns across the Himalayas.

title: Meet China’s ‘Full Time Children’: Why unemployed youths are working for their parents
landing_page_headline: Meet China’s ‘Full Time Children’: Why unemployed youths are working for their parents
description:
Amid China’s record youth unemployment levels, some young people are moving back home to work as paid ‘full-time children’. As their parents’ live-in personal assistants, they do simple chores and spend time with them in exchange for free rent or even a salary. Some document their daily routine as part of a viral online trend on Chinese social media.

But, not every family is fully onboard with this alternative ‘career’ decision. Some ‘full-time children’ report tensions at home and anxieties about their formal jobless status.

title: Peranakans in Australia: How we found our Nyonya identity as immigrants Down Under
description:
In their eagerness to fit in as immigrants in Australia, do newcomers lose their unique cultures? Can you honour one identity while embracing an adopted one?

These Straits Chinese migrants from Malaysia and Singapore felt culturally isolated and the pressure to assimilate. "It's hard to be Peranakan without someone else to be Peranakan with," one said.

This story is about how they found each other and formed a community in Melbourne; and a younger generation's wonder in re-discovering their nyonya and baba heritage. Can they preserve their traditions for the next generation of Australian-born "Peranakan possums"?

title: The Exiles - Singaporeans find long-lost family, 75 years after ‘White Australia’ policy tore them apart
landing_page_headline: Singaporeans find long-lost family, 75 years after ‘White Australia’ policy tore them apart
description: Armed with only their grandmother’s maiden name, Singaporean siblings Samson Zee and Lela Zainal had always wondered about her mysterious family she’d left behind in Australia nearly 75 years ago. When they started to search for answers in earnest, they discovered that their grandfather, Jacob Abdullah, was a mariner who had served the Australian navy during World War II - but was deported shortly after under the racist ‘White Australia Policy’. His Australian wife and children followed him to Singapore.

His Australian wife and children followed him to Singapore.

title: Stuck with low pay, how Taiwan’s young graduates cope with high costs
landing_page_headline: Stuck with low pay, how Taiwan’s young graduates cope with high costs
description:
Millennials in Taiwan are facing a new reality — high cost of living, stagnating wages and tougher competition for well-paying jobs. Despite getting university degrees, many are not better off financially than their parents’ generation. Some are just surviving, with no savings at the end of each month.

Unlike their parents, who entered the workforce in the 1980s during the golden era of wage growth in post-war Taiwan, youths today face single-digit economic growth and slow wage increases, amid overall inflation and the rising cost of housing.

CNA Insider follows the lives of a few ‘trapped’ youths to see what they’re doing to cope - including working up to 4 jobs, or going overseas to work in F&B jobs.

title: JUMP! - The science of military skydiving: Inside an elite team’s parachute display
landing_page_headline: The science of military skydiving: Inside an elite team’s parachute display
description:
Elite military display parachutists are renowned for their skillful jumps from high altitudes. But how do they make a precise landing within a small drop zone? What skills does it take to create their formations in freefall? Which unpredictable ground conditions can complicate the landing? And why does it take so much experience to be one of them?

The Red Lions, display parachuters who are part of the Singapore Armed Forces Parachute Team, are celebrated for their free fall performances at the annual National Day Parade. To be a Red Lion, rigorous training in both static line and military free fall jumps is essential, and there’s a requirement of at least 500 jumps.

Their precise aerial manoeuvres, synchronised choreography, and adept parachute control have practical value in military operations, where landing with accuracy and coordinated jumps are crucial.

title: Homeless In Singapore - Why I would rather sleep rough with pets than share a HDB rental flat: homeless man in Singapore
landing_page_headline: Why I would rather sleep rough with pets than share a HDB rental flat: homeless man in Singapore
description:
Hamad Bin Shukri, 64, has been homeless for 6 years, since he sold his house to pay his wife a divorce settlement.

With a passion for birdkeeping, he currently serves as a caretaker for a bird club and sleeps in a shed - he was offered its use after he had to move from his previous outdoor sleeping spot due to public complaints.

Although social workers offered to find him a public rental flat for permanent shelter, he turned down their assistance as he was not keen to share a flat with another person because of his pet birds.

title: The hospital that helps alcoholics stay out of the A&E
description:
Over the years, Khoo Teck Puat Hospital (KTPH) observed observed that the same patients with alcohol misuse issues kept returning to its emergency department. To alleviate this extra load on A&E resources, KTPH introduced the Alcohol-Related Frequent Attenders (ARFA) programme.

A team comprising a community nurse and a social worker visits such patients regularly where they live, helping to deal with psychosocial factors contributing to their alcoholism, referring them for further help if need be, and encouraging them to reduce their alcohol intake - all without judgement.

title: No sleep, 2 jobs: Young South Koreans seek to escape Hell Joseon rat race | Asia’s stuck generation
landing_page_headline: No sleep, 2 jobs: Young South Koreans seek to escape Hell Joseon rat race | Asia’s stuck generation
description:
South Korea may be home to K-pop and TV dramas, but life for the average young Korean is less glamorous. Millennials and Gen Zs in the country face high housing and other costs, and there is intense competition to get into top universities, which can determine one’s earning power and career opportunities for life. Many hold multiple jobs, or sleep only two to three hours a night.

The pressure is so intense that in 2021, South Korea’s suicide rate was the highest among OECD countries. Meanwhile, about 3.1 per cent of South Koreans aged 19 to 39 are recluses. CNA Insider meets four young Koreans who are trying to chart their own paths out of the rat race.

landing_page_headline: My parents don’t want to meet my LGBT partner. Should I push the issue?
description:
How far should LGBTQ young adults push for acceptance from their parents? Fitness and lifestyle content creator Cheryl Tay and film-maker Sean Foo talk about coming out to their parents and the reactions they got. Cheryl and Sean want to be able to bring their respective partners home to meet their families. But should they force the issue?

In a social experiment, they put their dilemma to a group of strangers, to find out what they would do in their shoes, and why.

title: How a job scam turned me into a scammer. I'm still seeking justice
landing_page_headline: How a job scam turned me into a scammer. I'm still seeking justice
description: Malaysian Bilce Tan answered what he thought was a legitimate job ad by a Malaysian recruiter. But when he arrived in Cambodia to start work, he discovered it was a scam - and was forced through threat of torture to work for a syndicate conducting online love scams on victims all over the world. His interview with CNA Insider reveals details of his harrowing experience, and how the scammers continue to ruin his life even after he escaped and returned to Malaysia, where he tried to search for justice.

title: Insight 2022/2023: Thailand’s eco monks upcycle trash into robes, fuel & school buildings
landing_page_headline: Thailand’s eco monks upcycle trash into robes, fuel & school buildings
description: In Thailand, abbot Phra Maha Pranom and Chak Daeng Temple have been spearheading a recycling revolution - believers, and even foreigners and companies, send the temple their trash that the monks then recycle into faux wood, fabric (even a beauty pageant gown) and fuel. It started when the monks developed a way to turn plastic bottles into yarn, which was then spun into their robes. The monks believe their recycling efforts will generate ‘merit’ and produce positive outcomes for the Earth that align with Lord Buddha’s teaching.

title: Insight 2022/2023: China’s bai lan Vs pro-996youth - Why should I work hard?
landing_page_headline: Bai lan VS pro-996 youth - Why should I work hard?
description:
In China, the ‘bailan’ movement - similar to quiet quitting - is about giving up on trying to get anywhere, and the motto of ‘let it rot’. It runs counter to the 996 work culture that’s a reference to the practise of working from 9am to 9pm, six days a week.

Zhang Yingqiu, 32, is an insurance agent who, though she stops short of working 996, agrees with its ethos of hard work being fulfilling. Wang Shuai, 26, is an escape room actor who does just enough at work to get by and believes in “lying flat”.

title: Riot Island: How Singapore’s open-concept prison on Pulau Senang ended in tragedy
landing_page_headline: How Singapore’s open-concept prison on Pulau Senang ended in tragedy
description:
Did you know that Singapore once had an open-concept ‘prison island’? In 1960, a penal settlement was set up on Pulau Senang, an island about 13km from the mainland. There were no bars nor fences and detainees were free to roam the island, with guards going unarmed.

Secret society members arrested under the 1955 Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) were sent there to rehabilitate through hard work and education. Then, it was hailed as a visionary concept for its low re-offending rate, until tragedy struck.

video.label: How Singapore’s open-concept prison on Pulau Senang ended in tragedy
video.caption:
Did you know that Singapore once had an open-concept ‘prison island’? In 1960, a penal settlement was set up on Pulau Senang, an island about 13km from the mainland. There were no bars nor fences and detainees were free to roam the island, with guards going unarmed. 

Secret society members arrested under the 1955 Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) were sent there to rehabilitate through hard work and education. Then, it was hailed as a visionary concept for its low re-offending rate, until tragedy struck.

title: Talking Point 2022/2023: Why fish prices are rising because of climate change.
landing_page_headline: Why fish prices are rising because of climate change?
description:
As of 2021, Singapore imported about 25% of its seafood from Malaysia. Three-quarters of Malaysia’s fish supply is wild-caught - but fish stocks have been shrinking and fishermen are having to go out further to sea for longer. As a result, their costs are rising - and so are retail prices.

Fish farms, too, have not been spared the impact of external factors like the war in Ukraine that has led to higher operational costs.

video.label: Why fish prices are rising because of climate change.

title: Meet the Zoomers: China Mum: I want my daughter to get into a good university. Is that too much to ask?
landing_page_headline: China Mum: I want my daughter to get into a good university. Is that too much to ask?
description: Li Shiying is a 15 year-old Chengdu teenager sitting for the senior high school enrolment exams. Her mum is anxious because she wants Shiying to go to the best school in the district, which would improve her chances of getting into university. But Shiying is passionate about her uniformed group club, and refuses to give up its activities to focus on her exams — which leads to fights with her mum, especially after her results are in.

title: Talking Point 2022/2023: Why fish prices are rising because of climate change
landing_page_headline: Why fish prices are rising because of climate change
description:
As of 2021, Singapore imported about 25% of its seafood from Malaysia. Three-quarters of Malaysia’s fish supply is wild-caught - but fish stocks have been shrinking and fishermen are having to go out further to sea for longer. As a result, their costs are rising - and so are retail prices.

Fish farms, too, have not been spared the impact of external factors like the war in Ukraine that has led to higher operational costs.

video.label: Why fish prices are rising because of climate change

landing_page_headline: JJ Lin’s tips if you’re struggling to learn mandarin (Or sing in it)
description:
On an earlier episode of #TalkingPoint on mother tongue education in Singapore, singer-songwriter Benjamin Kheng lamented about his struggle with trying to sing in Chinese. In this follow-up, presenter Steven Chia ropes in singer-songwriter JJ Lin (also, like Steven and Ben, an Anglo-Chinese School (ACS) alumni) to help out with some tips.

JJ speaks about his early years debuting in Taiwan when he struggled with Mandarin and had to almost “learn the whole language again” - and shares some tricks and tips.

title: I pose as a 13-year-old in a Metaverse chat room - Here’s what happened
landing_page_headline: I pose as a 13-year-old in a Metaverse chat room - Here’s what happened
description:
Is your child venturing into the Metaverse - and could they be getting into dangerous situations?

Talking Point host Munah Bagharib goes undercover as a 13-year-old in the popular chat room, VR Chat. Though there is an age limit of 18, it isn’t enforced in this chat room, so she encountered avatars of other users claiming to be aged 10 and 14. She definitely didn’t expect to witness explicit sexual acts between avatars. She was even followed by a stranger she had just met.

title: Undercover Asia: Confessions of tech support scammers: How we justify what we do
landing_page_headline: Confessions of tech support scammers: How we justify what we do
description: Scam IT support call centres are big businesses in India, which accounts for some 85% of such scams perpetrated globally. And they have a ready pool of recruits - drawing many Indians with legitimate-looking job ads that promise wages above the national average, performance incentives and a comfortable air-conditioned office. Others, however, stay on for the money. One scam operator said on a good night, he could make enough “for a year”. Some find ways to justify it with their conscience.

title: I was scammed of $77k - Here’s what you need to learn from my story
landing_page_headline: I was scammed of $77k - Here’s what you need to learn from my story
description: Han Ni fell for a pig butchering scam - a mash-up of romance and investment schemes run by Asia-based online scam syndicates. She reveals how scammers first developed an emotional intimacy by showing concern for her over a prolonged period. They then brainwashed her into investing in a fake platform despite her doubts. They also told her not to tell her loved ones about the platform when instructed to borrow money from them.

title: I fell for a love scam: How they made it seem so real
landing_page_headline: I fell for a love scam: How they made it seem so real
description: ‘Samantha’, a divorcee in her 50s from Malaysia, fell for a pig butchering scam - a mash-up of romance and investment schemes run by Asia-based online scam syndicates. When asked how it was possible to fall in love so quickly without having met the person in real life, Samantha said “it’s like going back to the days when we had penpals, the thing called letters”. Within months, Samantha lost about US$20,000. Looking back, Samantha said there were red flags that she should not have ignored. These are the lessons she’s learnt.

title: Insight 2022/2023: Why more Taiwanese are signing up for private military training?
landing_page_headline: Why more Taiwanese are signing up for private military training?
description: Since the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and with the uptick in tensions between China and the United States, more Taiwanese are seeing an attack by China on the island as likely – that’s 39% of survey respondents recently. And going by a March 2022 poll by the Taiwanese Public Opinion Foundation, 56% are sceptical that the US will send troops in defence of Taiwan. Those concerns have fuelled an increase in the number of private citizens signing up for urban warfare training at places like Polar Light Training centre, run by a military veteran.

Those concerns have fuelled an increase in the number of private citizens signing up for urban warfare training at places like Polar Light Training centre, run by a military veteran.

title: Insight 2022/2023: China millennials’ mortgage boycott: Why the property crisis?
landing_page_headline: China millennials’ mortgage boycott: Why the property crisis?
description: In 2022, Chinese millennial homebuyers took to the streets and social media to wage a boycott on mortgage payments, as their homes stood unfinished with financially distressed developers unable to complete them. Real estate and its related industries make up a hefty one-third of China’s economy. So, as Insight’s Wei Du explains, any property crisis would ripple out into the world - with reduced imports of steel and timber from countries like Australia and Indonesia, for instance.

title: Talking Point 2022/2023: I posed as a13-year-old in a metaverse chat room - Here’s what happened
landing_page_headline: I posed as a13-year-old in a metaverse chat room - Here’s what happened
description: "Is your child venturing into the Metaverse - and could they be getting into dangerous situations?" Talking Point host Munah Bagharib goes undercover as a 13-year-old in the popular chat room, VR Chat. Though there is an age limit of 18, it isn’t enforced in this chat room, so she encountered avatars of other users claiming to be aged 10 and 14. She definitely didn’t expect to witness explicit sexual acts between avatars, or be followed by a stranger she had just met.

title: The Baby Makers: Inside the world’s largest sperm bank, in a Denmark University town
landing_page_headline: Inside the world’s largest sperm bank, in a Denmark University town
description: There are over 800 sperm donors listed on Cryos International’s website as of August 2022. It’s said to be the world’s largest sperm bank. At the sperm facility in Aarhus, Denmark, donors have access to a variety of material, including virtual reality experiences that are said to improve sperm quality. Donor selection criteria include their medical history, travel frequency, lifestyle habits and sexual behaviour.

title: One Way:  Telling a different Hong Kong migrant story: What happened to the Chow family from One Way?
landing_page_headline: Telling a different Hong Kong migrant story: What happened to the Chow family from One Way?
description: One Way director Wei Du and director of photography Matt Ma speak about their experiences following the intimate and emotional journeys of Hong Kong migrants moving to the United Kingdom, in their compelling two-part documentary. Four months after it aired, Wei and Matt share updates on how the Chows - Fiona, Ah Man and their two kids - are adjusting to life in the UK. They also respond to viewers’ comments, including about the couple’s intense bickering on camera, racism in the UK, and whether there will be a sequel.

title: Life as a “left-behind child” in a poor mountain village in China
landing_page_headline: Life as a “Left-behind child” in a poor mountain village in China
description: Qiu He, 12, lives in school for most of the week and on his grandparents’ farm on weekends, in Ninglang Yi Autonomous County in northwest Yunnan. He sees his mother, who works in the city, only once or twice a year. The locals believe that education is their way out of rural poverty and to economic opportunities elsewhere. But Qiu He wants even more - he dreams of becoming a singer and “making a lot of money” to give his family a better life.

title: Undercover Asia: The women selling their unwanted pandemic babies in the Philippines
landing_page_headline: The women selling their unwanted pandemic babies in the Philippines
description: Buying a baby in the Philippines is as easy as putting up a Facebook post. Within a week, the Undercover Asia team received responses from ‘BMOMs’ or birth mothers asking for ‘adoption fees’ as low as US$100. description: Buntida ‘Faii’ Chinnawong is a make-up artist who shares her beauty secrets and everyday life with 5.8 million followers on #TikTok. Born without arms, the Thai #contentcreator is known for her cheeky sense of humour and dance moves. The ‘feet makeup artist’, as she is called, also has her share of cyberbullies and hateful comments. At her lowest, she spiralled into depression which was the "most difficult time" of her life. But she decided to fight back with humour, and now also tries to inspire others.

title: Silk Road 2.0: China in a Post-Pandemic World - S1E1:  Why China wants to own the world’s undersea Internet cables
landing_page_headline: Why China wants to own the world’s undersea Internet cables
description: Deep sea submarine data cables are the lifeblood of the world’s electronic communications, allowing for Zoom calls, credit card transactions and YouTube videos. It’s no wonder China is ramping up its ambitions to build, own and operate such cables, as part of its Digital Silk Road across the world. Chinese telcos like Huawei, Zte, China Telecom, China Mobile and China Unicom have been investing in the construction and maintenance of submarine cables. including as part of major international consortia. But China’s plans have raised serious security concerns in the West, with the potential for espionage and cyberwarfare. The US has deemed Chinese companies involved as a national security risk.

video.label: Why China wants to own the world’s undersea Internet cables

But China’s plans have raised serious security concerns in the West, with the potential for espionage and cyberwarfare. The US has deemed Chinese companies involved as a national security risk.

title: Insight 2021/2022 - S1: People of the Mekong fight for survival, in the shadow of China’s mega dams
description:
As part of its quest for carbon neutrality by 2060, China is planning to build the world’s biggest dam for a hydropower project on the Yarlung Tsango, or the Brahmaputra as it’s known in India. The river flows through Tibet, China, Bangladesh and India,.

But there are grave worries about the mega dam’s detrimental environmental impact, and how it might affect the downstream communities. The story of the Mekong river presents a cautionary precedent.

But there are grave worries about the mega dam’s detrimental environmental impact, and how it might affect the downstream communities. The story of the Mekong river presents a cautionary precedent.

title: Insight 2021/2022 - S1: Why aren’t Indonesia and The Philippines getting the vaccines they need?
description: There is a glaring global inequity in the distribution of COVID-19 vaccines. As of Aug 12, 2021, only 9.6% of Indonesia’s population and 10.8% of the Philippines’ population were vaccinated as compared to rates of 50% in the US and 53% in Europe, according to the Bloomberg vaccine tracked.

As of Aug 12, 2021, only 9.6% of Indonesia’s population and 10.8% of the Philippines’ population were vaccinated as compared to rates of 50% in the US and 53% in Europe, according to the Bloomberg vaccine tracked.

title: Missing Dakota:  How Relocation Impacts The Elderly - Life, Uprooted (1/2)
description:
In 2016, residents of the Old Kallang Airport Housing Estate at Dakota Crescent began moving out, as the estate - one of Singapore's oldest - was marked for redevelopment. The roughly 400 households of the rental housing estate had been given about two years' notice, and the opportunity to move to brand-new rental flats at a nearby block - 52 Cassia Crescent.

While the modern flats with elderly-friendly universal design features promised seniors a fresh start, for some, the sense of dislocation and unhappiness was tough to deal with. Not only were daily haunts like the market and hawker centre further away now - up to a 30-minute walk for an elderly person with weak legs - the activity centre that was at the heart of residents' social interactions was not moving with them.

From early 2019, CNA Insider tracked how these older residents had fared in the years after being relocated, and looked at the dangers of isolation and disengagement that can result.

video.label: Missing Dakota:  How Relocation Impacts The Elderly - Life, Uprooted (1/2)
video.caption:
In 2016, residents of the Old Kallang Airport Housing Estate at Dakota Crescent began moving out, as the estate - one of Singapore's oldest - was marked for redevelopment. The roughly 400 households of the rental housing estate had been given about two years' notice, and the opportunity to move to brand-new rental flats at a nearby block - 52 Cassia Crescent.

While the modern flats with elderly-friendly universal design features promised seniors a fresh start, for some, the sense of dislocation and unhappiness was tough to deal with. Not only were daily haunts like the market and hawker centre further away now - up to a 30-minute walk for an elderly person with weak legs - the activity centre that was at the heart of residents' social interactions was not moving with them.

From early 2019, CNA Insider tracked how these older residents had fared in the years after being relocated, and looked at the dangers of isolation and disengagement that can result.

author: Ruth Smalley

title: Bye, Tanglin Halt: How Will The Elderly Cope With Relocation? Life, Uprooted (2/2)
description:
In a few months' time, one of Singapore's oldest estates, Tanglin Halt, will be an empty shell with the last of some 3,480 households finally moving out. It's all part of the Selective En-Bloc Redevelopment Scheme (SERS) to rejuvenate older housing estates, and affected residents have been progressively relocated to new flats at five nearby sites, at Dawson estate.

But while this means modern new amenities for residents, the big move is disrupting social support networks for the elderly. The Tanglin Halt "kampung" had been all about neighbours, hawkers and shopkeepers looking out for the vulnerable - including one activity centre that was "like family" to the elderly. Who will fill that gap when this community is broken up?

CNA Insider tracked some of the elderly residents over two years - including in the wake of the COVID-19 ‘circuit breaker’ which threw into painful relief the effects of social isolation on the elderly.

title: Interracial Couples React To Viral Racist Video
description:
When they first saw the viral racist video, Indian-Chinese couple Martin and Esther couldn't believe such overt racism still exists in Singapore. But for another interracial couple Norsham and Anne, it only reminded them of the prejudice that existed in their own family. 

All of them think that we need to have more open conversations about race and racism in Singapore. Do you agree?

video.caption:
When they first saw the viral racist video, Indian-Chinese couple Martin and Esther couldn't believe such overt racism still exists in Singapore. But for another interracial couple Norsham and Anne, it only reminded them of the prejudice that existed in their own family. 

All of them think that we need to have more open conversations about race and racism in Singapore. Do you agree?

author: Goh Chiew Tong

title: Talking Point 2020/2021 - S1: What makes tempered glass doors or cookware shatter?
description: Tempered glass is used everywhere from screen protectors for phones to cookware, oven doors, kitchen hobs, and shower panels. At least 530 glass panels were reported to have suddenly shattered over the past 10 years. This happens because an impurity - nickel sulphide - in tempered glass, and micro-cracks or chips that may come about with improper handling.

title: Living in a village that's sinking into the sea
description: In Sitio Pariahan in the Philippines, villagers attend Sunday mass in a flooded church, while all roads have vanished underwater. The sinking village is situated on Manila Bay, where a combination of climate change, rise in sea level, the disappearance of mangrove swamps and land subsidence has made the area increasingly prone to floods and typhoon damage.

title: Why Manila is sinking
description: Manila is sinking fast, with simulations showing that Manila City could sink by 2 metres in just 40 years, by 2060. The sea level at Manila bay is also rising 4x faster than the rest of the world. The problem is caused by overpopulation and the over extraction of groundwater. Despite the government’s imposition of a moratorium, illegal extraction carried on.

Bottles passed off as popular brands can be bought cheaply at provision shops in Penang for instance, but instead of the real thing they contain improperly distilled alcohol with deadly traces of methanol. In Penang, local authorities continue to crack down, but enforcement is an uphill challenge.

video.label: Death by alcohol: Counterfeit liquor in Malaysia
video.caption: Since 2018, bootleg alcohol has taken the lives of at least 33 consumers in Malaysia. Bottles passed off as popular brands can be bought cheaply at provision shops in Penang for instance, but instead of the real thing they contain improperly distilled alcohol with deadly traces of methanol. In Penang, local authorities continue to crack down, but enforcement is an uphill challenge.

title: Safety measures in place, but expert sees greater risk of sinkholes with climate change
description: With all the construction work underway in Singapore, the programme Talking Point explores the concerns about geological safety when it comes to sinkholes and finds out what you can do if the earth swallows you.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Measures to manage the risk of sinkholes during construction work include using radar to detect underground voids.

  • But a hotter, wetter future will put a greater strain on the ground beneath Singapore’s concrete jungle.

  • Those who travel in the region should be wary in limestone-rich areas, especially if there are periods of high rainfall or drought.

author: Faith Leong

#attributes.alt: Safety measures in place, but expert sees greater risk of sinkholes with climate change
#attributes.title: Safety measures in place, but expert sees greater risk of sinkholes with climate change

title: New thorns in town? Here’s why Tupai King, other new durian varieties may be mislabelled
description: In each durian season, flashy names beckon customers. But are they the real deal or simply marketing ploys? The programme Talking Point finds out what durians are really being sold and how to avoid falling for thorny cash grabs.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• New durian varieties are shaking up the market, promising unique flavours and textures, but there’s a question of authenticity.
  • The Penang farmer certified to have registered the name Tupai King says he hasn’t exported his durians to Singapore.
  • Some other varieties are just elaborate names for variations on Mao Shan Wang, say durian experts.

author: Faith Leong

#attributes.alt: New thorns in town? Here’s why Tupai King, other new durian varieties may be mislabelled
#attributes.title: New thorns in town? Here’s why Tupai King, other new durian varieties may be mislabelled
